sent_inference: I enjoy going sailing with my father.
Some of the cookies at the bakery are chocolate.
I don't like eating out at upscale places.
Some of the movies at the theater are comedies.
sent_manipulation: Bob spends a lot of time with his family.
John has been to the bakery and looked at the new cookies.
Bob has only had the chance to see one of the movies showing at the theater.
sent_context: John and Bob were talking about sailing yesterday.
A few days ago, John and Bob were talking about the current selection of cookies at a local bakery.
John and Bob were talking about restaurants yesterday.
Yesterday, John and Bob were talking about the movies at a local theater.
expt_aim: Deciding what "some" means in plain English.
sent_question: he enjoys walking in the woods alone?
not all of the cookies at the bakery are chocolate?
he doesn't like eating at fancy restaurants?
not all of the movies at the theater are comedies?
speaker: Bob
John
John
Bob
expt_gen: Strictly speaking, "some" means "at least one," so the word "some" is broad enough to be true if all of the elements of a set have a characteristic.  If all cookies were chocolate, then "some cookies are chocolate" is true.  However, when we use "some" in plain language, we imply that there are elements of the set that don't share the characteristic.  For example, "some cookies are chocolate" implies "some cookies are not chocolate."
character_thoughts: I don't have any strong conclusions about John or Bob based on the activities they engaged in.
